# Computer System Overview

------

## Introduction

#### Computers have a combination of Hardware and Software

#### Hardware

The physical electronic components, eg., keyboard, monitor

#### Software

Recorded instructions and programs that govern the working of a computer

##### Programs

It's a set of instructions to carry out a specific task or achieve a special work goal

## Components and Organization

#### A computer system has 5 basic components:

#### 1. Input Unit

It's responsible for taking input

#### 2. Output Unit

It's responsible for giving output

#### 3. CPU

It's responsible for processing data and instructions. It consists of:

##### (i) ALU (Arithmetic and Logic Unit)

Carries out arithmetic instructions (add, subtract, multiply, divide) and making logical decisions (greater than, less than, equal to)

##### (ii) CU (Control Unit)

Controls and supervises the processing

#### 4. Primary Memory

**Internal volatile** memory where data and instructions are stored during processing

#### 5. Secondary Storage Unit

External storage devices which provide **permanent** memory

![img](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Von_Neumann_Architecture.svg/510px-Von_Neumann_Architecture.svg.png)

### Computer Organisation

- The logical structure of a computer system is computer organisation
- Computers follow the IPO principle, i.e., Input --> Process --> Output

![img](https://miro.medium.com/max/1838/1*gMXS5fppbPG3hhcPDb0eeA.jpeg)

### Input Unit

- Consists of the input devices attached to the computer
- Converts input into computer understandable form (binary code)
- Inputs consist of data as well as instruction
- Some input devices are:

#### (i) Keyboard

A typewriter like device used to type in letters, digits and commands. Braille keyboards are also available.

#### (ii) Mouse

A pointing device with either a roller on its base or a laser mechanism.

#### (iii) Microphone

Used for sound input. A mic converts the sound received into computer's format, which is called **digitized sound** or **digital audio**. A mic needs a sound card.

### Output Unit

- Consists of the output devices attached to the computer
- Converts output into human understandable form (characters, graphical or audio-visual form)
- Some output devices are:

#### (i) Monitor

It's the most common form of output. It consists of thousands of tiny colored dots called pixels. Braille monitors are also available.

#### (ii) Printer

It delivers output by means of printed characters on paper. Printers can be inkjet, laserjet, dot-matrix etc.

#### (iii) Speaker

It receives the sound in form of elctric current from the sound card and then convert it to sound format audible to user

### CPU

- It's called "The Brain of the Computer" as it guides, directs, controls and governs the performance of a computer.

#### (i) ALU

- Arithmetic operations: +, -, *, /
- Logical operations: <, >, =, <=, >=, !=

#### (ii) CU

- Controls and guides the interpretation, flow and manipulation of all data
- Another important function is **program execution**

#### (iii) Registers aka Processor Registers

- Small units of data holding places
- Used to temporarily hold processing-info when processing takes place

### Memory

- A pre-defined working place, where the computer temporarily keeps info and data to facilitate its performance
- Each memory location has a unique memory address
- A bit means a *bi*nary digi*t*
- A group of 8 bits is called a **byte** and a group of 4 bits is called a **nibble**
- One byte is the smallest unit which can represent a date item or a character.
- Every higher memory unit is equal to 210 of its lower unit.

![image.png](data:image/png;base64,)

#### Parts Of Memory

#### (i) Dynamic RAM (DRAM)

- Made up of **transistors and capacitors**
- The amount of time taken to produce data required from memory, from the start of access until the availability of data is called **memory access time**
- Today's DRAM chips have access times ranging from **below 20 to 70 nanoseconds**
- Used in the primary storage section of most computers

#### (ii) Static RAM (SRAM)

- Made up of **flip-flops**
- Offers faster access times (about 10 nanoseconds) than DRAM
- Used in **specialized applications**

### Read Only Memory (ROM)

- Performs only read operation; doesn't have a write capability
- ROM is used for applications in which it is known that the info never needs to be altered, e.g., a monitor program controlling a machine
- Slower than RAM
- Various types are ROM are:

#### (i) PROM (Programmable ROM)

- Also called OTP (One Time Programmable)
- User programmable memory
- Info is burnt using a ROM burner

#### (ii) EPROM (Erasable Programmable ROM)

- Programmable using **UV radiation**
- The UV-EPROM can take upto 20 mins for erasing EPROM contents

#### (iii) EEPROM (Electrically Erasable Programmable ROM)

- Faster erasing than EPROM
- **Selective** bytes can be erased unlike EPROM

#### (iv) Flash EEPROM

- Very fast, i.e., takes less than a second to erase all the contents
- Erases fully and not selectively

#### (v) Mask ROM

- Contents are programmed by the IC manufacturer
- Not a user-programmable ROM

### Cache Memory

- A special high-speed storage mechanism available inside CPU in order to speed up access to data and instructions stored in RAM memory
- A memory cache (aka cache store or RAM cache) is a portion of memory made of high-speed SRAM
- When data is found in the cache, it is called a **cache hit**, and the effectiveness of a cache is judged by its hit rate
- 95% of the time the processor is working, it is accessing information from cache

### Storage Unit

- A computer needs to store and retrieve data for processing
- Since primary memory is temporary, secondary storage devices are used for permanent data storage
- Some common storage devices are:

#### (i) Hard Disk

- Stores info on one or more **circular platters** (or disks) which are continually **spinning**
- Coated with a magnetic material and stacked with space between them
- Info is recorded as tiny magnetic spots
- Storage capacity from GBs to TBs

#### (ii) CD

- Relatively cheap
- Storage capacity of upto 700MB
- There are 3 types of CDs: 
  - **CD-ROM**:
    - Only used to store info and can't be used to store data
    - Used for CD distribution, e.g., software, games etc. 
  - **CD-R**
    - Written on only once and can't be erased 
  - **CD-RW**
    - An erasable disk which can be re-written multiple times

#### (iii) DVD

- Holds 15 times as much info and trnasfers 20 times as fast as a CD-ROM
- Also called **Super Density disk (SD)**
- Storage capacity up to 17 GB
- There are 3 types of DVDs:
  - **DVD-ROM**
  - **DVD-R**
  - **DVD-RW**

#### (iv) Flash Memory

- A small ultra-portable device with **solid-state memory**, i.e., has no moving parts nor laser mechanism
- Works in a similar way to RAM, but data is retained
- Fairly inexpensive
- Storage capacity ranges from 256 MB to 128 GB and beyond

#### (v) Blue Ray Disk

- Optical disc storage media format
- Used for HD video and data storage
- Blu-Ray uses blue-violet (405 nm) laser instead of red (650 nm)
- As blue-violet has a **shorter wavelength** than red, data can be packed more tightly
- Storage capacity upto 128 GB

### System Bus

- An **electronic pathway** composed of connecting cables connecting major components
- Data carrying part of bus --> Data bus
- Control instruction carrying part --> Control bus
- Memory address carrying part --> Address bus
- A separate type of bus called I/O Bus connects input, output and other external devices

## Mobile System Organization

- Handle diverse types of applications such as:
  1. Making calls through radio signals
  2. Offering camera utilities
  3. Handling touch-sensitive screen
  4. Display audio/video/graphical content
- The functional components of a mobile system are:

### Mobile Processor (Mobile CPU)

- Brain of a smartphone
- It has two major sub-processors:
  - **Communications Processing Unit** (Mobile I/O Unit):
    - Responsible for making and receiving phone calls
    - It has a digital signal processor that helps it work with RF Transceiver and the Audio subsystem
    - **Radio Signal Management Unit** connects SIM to base stations through radio signals 
  - (ii) **Applications Processing Unit**:
    - Responsible for governing, controlling all types of operations by running mobile apps

### Display Subsystem

- Responsible for providing display facilities, touch sensitive interface and keyboards

### Camera Subsystem

- Designed to deliver a tightly bound image processing package
- It has an integrateed Image Signal Processor and it ensures
  1. Instant image capture
  2. High-resolution support
  3. Image stabilization
  4. Other image enhancements

### Mobile System Memory

#### (i) RAM:

- Work memory of mobile system
- The more RAM, the better the performance #### (ii) ROM:
- Not accessible for users to write on
- Basically Flash memory or technically EEPROM
- Contains OS and other pre-installed apps

### Storage

- Also called expandable storage
- Form of SD cards, micro SD cards
- Even cloud storage is external storage

### Power Management Subsystem (Battery)

- Responsible for providing power in required form
- Contains a battery management system that works with a battery charger and a battery unit

## Types Of Software

- Software represents the set of programs that govern the operation of a computer system and make the software run
- Software can be classified as:
  1. System Software
  2. Application Software

### System Software

- The software that controls internal computer operations such as:
  1. Reading data from input devices
  2. Transmitting info to output devices
  3. Checking system components
  4. Converting data to computer understandable form
- System Software can be classified into:
  (i) Operating System (ii) Language Processor

#### Operating System

- Primary goal - Make the computer convenient to use
- Secondary goal - Use computer hardware in an efficient manner
- Major components of a computer system are:
  1. Hardware
  2. OS
  3. Application program routines
  4. Humanware
- Hardware - Provides basic computing resources
- Application program routines - Defines the ways in which resources can be used
- OS - Controls and coordinates the use of hardware among the various apps
- Some types of OS are:
  1. Single User OS
  2. Multiuser OS
  3. Time sharing OS
  4. Real time OS
  5. Multiprocessing OS
  6. Distributed OS

#### Language Processors

- Source code - Program code written by a programmer in a HLL
- Object code - Code usually in machine language or binary code, a language that computer can easily understand
- A language processor translates source code into an object code
- 3 types of language processors:
  1. Assembler: Assembly Language --> Machine Language
  2. Interpreter: Translates and executes line by line
  3. Compiler: Translates and executes in one go
- The translated machine code runs faster than source code which requires conversion before executing

### Application Software

- Pertains to one specific application
- They can further be divided into 4 categories:
  1. Packages
  2. Utilities
  3. Customized Software
  4. Developer Tools

#### Packages

- A software can't be designed for every application, hence general software called packages are used
- Major categories of general software packages are:
  1. Word Processing Software
  2. Spreadsheets
  3. Database Management Systems
  4. Desktop Publishing Software
  5. Graphics, Multimedia and Presentation Applications

#### Utilities

- Programs that assist the computer by performing house-keeping functions
- It ensures the smooth functioning of the computer
- Some important utilities are: ##### (i) Text Editor
- Used for creating, editing text files

##### (ii) Backup Utility

- Facilitates the backing-up of disk
- Back-up means duplicating the disk information so that in case of any damage or data-loss, this backed-up data may be used

##### (iii) Compression Utility

- Facilitates compression of files
- Large files can be compressed so that they take up less space

##### (iv) Disk Defragmenter

- A file is fragmented when it's too large to store in a single location on a disk
- Disk Defragmenter speeds up disk access by rearranging the files and free space so that they are contiguous

##### (v) Antivirus Software

- A computer virus is a malicious computer program that disrupts normal functioning
- An antivirus software scans disk for viruses and removes them, if they are found

#### Business Software

- Specifically created for business requirements
- Examples:
  1. Inventory Management System: For managing inventory details
  2. Payroll System: For handling payroll of employees
  3. Financial Accounting
  4. Hotel Management
  5. Reservation System

### Software Libraries

- A pre-written set of code available to do a variety of tasks, which programmers can directly use in their code, are called software libraries
- Software libraries combine codes/scripts on the basis of their common domain
- Examples:
  1. NumPy (Numerical Python): Provides an abundance of of useful features/functions for numeric arrays and matrices
  2. SciPy (Scientific Python): Contains modules for linear algebra, optimization, integration and statistics
  3. Panda Library: Designed to work with "labeled" and "relational" data; for quick and easy data manipulation, aggregation and visualization

------
